Mixed oxides derived from MgAl, ZnAl, and MgZnAl hydrotalcites were prepared and modified with tin and iron using co-precipitation and impregnation methods. Comprehensive characterization by XRD, XRF, BET, TPD, TGA, SEM, and EDX revealed that metal composition and method of modification strongly influenced crystallinity, surface area, and acid-base properties. Tin incorporation increased acidity and basicity, while iron reduced both, with structural impacts varying by matrix. The catalysts were tested in the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of myrtenal and β-cyclocitral. ZnAl-based oxides showed the highest conversion and selectivity (almost total conversion of both starting substances after 5 h of the reaction, with selectivity to nopinone reaching approximately 95 % and selectivity to the products of β-cyclocitral oxidation around 70 %, predominantly yielding formate), while tin-modified MgAl catalysts provided stable performance with enhanced selectivity. Substrate structure significantly influenced product distribution, with myrtenal favouring oxidation–hydrolysis pathways and β-cyclocitral undergoing additional reduction. Reusability studies demonstrated excellent stability of SnMgAl catalysts over three consecutive reaction cycles, with minimal leaching and full recovery of crystallinity after recalcination. In contrast, SnZnAl catalysts showed gradual deactivation, especially when tin was introduced via impregnation. The study highlights the importance of fine-tuning acid-base and structural properties of mixed oxides through metal incorporation and preparation method. The findings offer valuable insights into the rational design of robust and selective catalysts for Baeyer-Villiger oxidations. Graphical Abstract Keywords Baeyer-Villiger oxidation Hydrotalcites Mixed oxides, beta-cyclocitral Myrtenal Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The transformation of ketones or aldehydes into lactones or esters using an oxidizing agent has been known since the 19th century as Baeyer-Villiger oxidation [1,2]. When Baeyer and Villiger discovered this reaction, they used peroxyacids as oxidizing agents [1]. Later, it was found that more stable and environmentally safer peroxides, such as hydrogen peroxide, could also drive the reaction. However, as peroxides are less active oxidizing agents than peroxyacids, the addition of a catalyst became necessary when using peroxides [2,3]. Heterogeneous catalysts are particularly popular for BV oxidation due to their higher selectivity, stability, ease of separation from the reaction mixture, recyclability, and more [2,3]. These catalysts include, for instance, metal-modified zeolites [4], mesoporous materials [5,6], hydrotalcites [3,7,8] and their derivatives [2,9–14]. In this work, attention is focused on mixed oxides derived from hydrotalcites. Hydrotalcites, also known as layered double hydroxides or anionic clays, have a layered structure similar to brucites, with base layers composed of Me2 + (Mg2+, Zn2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Co2+) hydroxides. When some Me2+ ions in these layers are replaced with Me3+ ions (Al3+, Cr3+, Fe3+, Ga3+), the layers acquire a positive charge, which is compensated by anions located in the interlayer spaces along with crystalline water molecules. The chemical composition of hydrotalcites can be expressed as [MII 1-xMIII x(OH)2]x+ [An- x/n·yH2O]x, where MII and MIII represent divalent and trivalent metal cations, respectively, and An- is an n-valent anion [7,15]. The value of x, typically in the range of 0.20–0.33, represents the proportion of trivalent cations in the hydroxide layers [16–19]. The anions in the interlayers are relatively weakly bound and can be exchanged under certain conditions. Although hydrotalcites are generally stable, at high temperatures (400–500 °C), water and anions are released from the interlayers, leading to decomposition of the layered structure and the formation of mixed oxides [20,21]. Hydrotalcites and their metal-modified derivatives have been shown to be highly effective catalysts for BV oxidation reactions. Ma et al. [22] successfully synthesized FeSnO mixed oxides and demonstrated their catalytic performance in the BV oxidation of cyclohexanone. Additionally, Mg2Fe-LDH was evaluated for the same reaction by Fang et al. [23] and proved effective for the BV oxidation of other cyclic ketones as well. Further studies in articles [24,25] explored the synthesis and catalytic testing of iron-based hydrotalcites for similar reactions. Olszówka et al. investigated MgAl hydrotalcites as catalysts for the BV oxidation of ε-caprolactone and cyclohexanone with H2O2/acetonitrile, focusing on the impact of the MgAl ion ratio [17], crystallinity [18], and particle size [26] on catalytic activity. Other researchers, referenced in articles [8,20,27,28], also dealt with the preparation and characterization of MgAl hydrotalcites and their derived mixed oxides, testing their catalytic activity in BV oxidation of cyclohexanone. Notably, MgAl hydrotalcites modified with tin exhibited high catalytic activity for BV oxidation [29]. Zhou et al. [30] reported the preparation of bifunctional Zn2Al hydrotalcites intercalated with cobalt tetraphenylporphyrin or copper tetrasulfophthalocyanine, which were effective in BV oxidation of ketones. Meanwhile, the authors of paper [15] synthesised unique hierarchical three-dimensional (3D) hydrotalcites with SiO2 binding, which they utilized as catalysts for the BV oxidation of several cyclic ketones. The authors of references [31] and [32] successfully employed modified MgFe and NiFe hydrotalcites as catalysts in several important organic reactions. In the epoxidation of cyclooctene and the oxidation of isoeugenol to vanillin, the most active material was a Mo-stabilized MgFe hydrotalcite. For the dehydrogenation of hexanol, a NiFe hydrotalcite intercalated with silicate and impregnated with ruthenium was used. In our previous studies [33–35], we investigated the catalytic activity of MgAl and SnMgAl hydrotalcites, as well as their derived mixed oxides impregnated with tin, in the BV oxidation of various aldehydes. The result showed that SnMgAl hydrotalcites prepared via the co-precipitation method were less active under the same conditions than MgAl hydrotalcites modified by the impregnation of tin. We also examined the impact of different precursors for incorporating tin and iron into the structure of MgAl hydrotalcites via co-precipitation. It was found that the choice of Sn precursor significantly influenced the acid-base properties of the prepared hydrotalcites and, consequently, their catalytic performance [21]. Based on these findings, the following question arose: could the catalytic activity of hydrotalcites prepared by the co-precipitation method for BV oxidation be enhanced by modifying their structural and acid-base properties? To address this, we focused in this study on the synthesis and characterization of mixed oxides based on hydrotalcites with varying molar ratios of Sn, Fe, Zn, Mg, and Al ions, prepared through the co-precipitation method. Additionally, we compared their catalytic activity with that of hydrotalcites modified via tin impregnation for the BV oxidation of two structurally different aldehydes. The catalytic activity of the synthesized materials was tested in two model reactions: the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of myrtenal to 6,6-dimethyl-bicyclo[3,1,1]-hept-2-en-2-yl formate and its subsequent hydrolysis to nopinone, and the BV oxidation of β-cyclocitral to 2,6,6-trimethylcyclohex-1-en-1-yl formate (referred to hereafter as "formate") and its subsequent hydrolysis to 2,6,6-trimethylcyclohexanone ( Fig. 1). In both reactions, the targeted products were formate and its hydrolysis product. However, in the BV oxidation of myrtenal, formate was immediately converted to nopinone upon formation, so only nopinone was detected in the reaction mixture as the desired product. A 50 % aqueous solution of hydrogen peroxide was used as the oxidizing agent. In the literature, two distinct mechanisms have been proposed for the Baeyer–Villiger oxidation of ketones when using hydrotalcite-based catalysts in combination with hydrogen peroxide as the oxidant. The first pathway requires the use of a nitrile-containing solvent such as benzonitrile or acetonitrile [28,29,36] (Fig. 1 S a) and b), SI). In this mechanism, hydrogen peroxide initially interacts with Brønsted basic sites on the catalyst surface, forming a hydroperoxide species. This species then reacts with the nitrile solvent to generate a peroxycarboximidic acid intermediate. This reactive intermediate subsequently attacks the ketone molecule adsorbed on the Lewis acidic site of the catalyst, forming a Criegee intermediate, which undergoes rearrangement to yield the final oxidation product [28]. The second mechanistic route proceeds without the need for a nitrile solvent but requires the catalyst to be modified with metal species—such as tin—that can facilitate activation of the carbonyl group (Fig. 1 S c) and d), SI). In this scenario, the ketone coordinates directly to the Lewis acid site of the catalyst, thereby increasing the electrophilicity of the carbonyl carbon. This activated carbonyl is then susceptible to nucleophilic attack by hydrogen peroxide, leading to formation of a Criegee intermediate that rearranges into the corresponding ester or lactone [14]. This mechanism is most commonly associated with tin-containing catalysts, particularly Sn-Beta zeolites and Sn-MCM-41 materials [13,37]. Based on our previous studies [33], it has been confirmed that under the experimental conditions applied in this work (see Section 2.3), the Baeyer–Villiger oxidation proceeds via both of these mechanisms. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts 2.1.1 Chemicals used Myrtenal (97 % purity) and a standard of nopinone (98 % purity) were purchased from Merck, while β-cyclocitral (96 % purity) was obtained from BLDpharm. Acetonitrile (p.a.), used as a solvent, as well as magnesium nitrate (Mg(NO3)2·6 H2O), zinc nitrate (Zn(NO3)2·6 H2O), aluminum nitrate (Al(NO3)3·9 H2O), iron nitrate (Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O), tin(IV) chloride (SnCl4·5 H2O), potassium hydroxide (KOH), and potassium carbonate (K2CO3) were obtained from Lach-Ner, s.r.o., tin(II) chloride (SnCl2·2 H2O) was sourced from Penta. Hydrogen peroxide (50 % aqueous solution), used as the oxidizing agent, was purchased from Carl Roth. 2.1.2 Preparation of mixed oxides (Sn/Fe)MgAl, (Sn)ZnAl and (Sn)MgZnAl hydrotalcites were prepared by co-precipitating two solutions: a basic solution and a metal salts solution. The precipitation process was carried out at a constant pH of 9.5 and a temperature of 60 °C using of Syrris Globe reactor (Syrris, Royston, Herts, UK). The basic solution was prepared by dissolving potassium hydroxide (KOH concentration = 2 mol/dm³) and potassium carbonate (K2CO3 concentration = 0.2 mol/dm³) in demineralized water. The metal precursors solution, prepared in demineralized water, contained metal salts (Mg(NO3)2·6 H2O, Zn(NO3)2·6 H2O, Al(NO3)3·9 H2O, Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O, SnCl4·5 H2O) in the required proportions, with a total metal ion concentration of 1 mol/dm³ . Both solutions were gradually pumped into the precipitation reactor, maintained at the target temperature, and allowed to precipitate for 1 h with constant stirring. The resulting solid precipitate was filtered using a filter press and washed with water until the pH became neutral. The filter cake obtained was dried overnight 110 °C and then calcined at 400 °C for 5 h to obtain the mixed oxides (MO). 2.1.3 Tin impregnation To test the influence of the method of tin incorporation into the hydrotalcite structure, a portion of the prepared MgAl, ZnAl and MgZnAl mixed oxides was subsequently impregnated with 3 and 5 wt% of tin. For this purpose, the required amount of tin(II) chloride dihydrate (SnCl2·2 H2O) was dissolved in a methanol-water solution (molar ratio of MeOH to H2O = 1:1, concentration = 0.002 mol/l). The appropriate amount of mixed oxide was then added to this solution, and the resulting suspension was stirred for 24 h at room temperature. After tin impregnation, the catalyst was filtered and washed first with demineralized water and then with methanol. It was then dried overnight at 110 °C and subsequently calcined at 400 °C for 5 h. 2.1.4 Catalysts designation One of the primary goals of this research was to compare the catalytic activity of materials that initially differed in their acid-base and surface properties. To achieve this, mixed oxides based on MgAl, ZnAl and MgZnAl hydrotalcites were synthesized. The prepared catalysts were designated using a specific model: the index number following the symbol of each metal indicates the molar ratio of that metal’s ions to the ions of the other metals in the mixed oxide synthesized via the co-precipitation method. If a metal symbol lacks an index number - commonly the case for aluminium (Al) - it signifies that the molar ratio of that metal to the others is 1. For example, in the mixed oxide labeled Sn0.35Fe0.15Mg2Al, the molar ratios of metal ions correspond to Sn:Fe:Mg:Al = 0.35:0.15:2:1. In the case of mixed oxides modified with tin via the impregnation method, the number preceding Sn denotes its weight percentage relative to the total weight of unmodified mixed oxide. For instance, a mixed oxide with a ZnAl molar ratio of 2, impregnated with 5 wt% of Sn, would be designated as 5Sn-Zn2Al. 2.1.5 Recycling of catalysts The stability of the prepared catalysts was verified by testing their reusability. After being used in the reaction, the catalyst was filtered, washed with acetonitrile, dried overnight at 110 °C, calcined in air at 400 °C for 5 h, and then used in the subsequent reaction cycle. 2.2 Characterisation of prepared catalysts 2.2.1 X-ray fluorescence analysis (XRF) X-ray fluorescence analysis (XRF) was used to determine the catalysts’ composition. Analysis was performed on an ARL 9400XP sequential WD-XRF spectrometer (Thermo ARL, Ecublens, Switzerland) equipped with an Rh anode end-window X-ray tube of type 4GN fitted with a 75 μm Be window. The intensities of the elements’ spectral lines were measured under vacuum using the WinXRF program. The generating settings-collimator-crystal-detector combinations were optimized for all 79 measured elements with an analysis time of 6 s per element. Data were evaluated using Uniquant 4 software tool. 2.2.2 Nitrogen Adsorption Measurements The specific surface area of all prepared catalysts was measured by nitrogen physisorption on NOVA 2000e from Quantachrome Instruments Boynton Beach, FL, USA. Before the analysis, the samples were degassed at 390 °C for 2 h. Measurements were performed at the boiling temperature of liquid nitrogen (77 K). The values of the specific surface area were determined from the course of the nitrogen isotherm in the area of relative pressures from 0 to 0.3 using the BET-equation. The specific surface was evaluated from a 12-point isotherm. 2.2.3 Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) The acid-base properties of the prepared catalysts were determined using temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of both CO2 and pyridine. TPD was performed on a Micromeritics Instrument, AutoChem II 2920, equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a quadrupole mass spectrometer (MKS Cirrus 2 Analyzer) with a capillary coupling system for detecting of desorbed CO2/pyridine. Before the analysis, the material (0.06 g) was inserted into a quartz U-shaped tube, heated under a helium flow (30 mL min–1) up to 400 °C, and kept at 400 °C for 60 min to remove impurities from the sample. Afterwards, the sample was cooled down to an adsorption temperature of 40 °C (CO2) or 150 °C (pyridine). Measured pulses of sorption gas (pulse volume, 5 mL) were injected into the helium and carried through the sample until adsorption saturation. After flushing the sample with helium for 60 min and removing physisorbed gas, the linear temperature program (10 °C min–1) was started at a temperature of 40 °C, and the sample was heated up to a temperature of 600 °C. The calibration of the intensity of the 44 (CO2) or 79 (pyridine) amu MS response was carried out to determine the amount of desorbed CO2/pyridine. 2.2.4 X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was used to determine crystallographic structure of the prepared catalysts. The analysis was carried out using an X-Pert3 Powder θ-θ powder diffractometer in a Bragg-Brentano parafocusing geometry with CuKα radiation wavelength (λ = 1.5421 Å, U = 40 kV, I = 30 mA) at room temperature. Part of the apparatus was an ultrafast 1D PIXCEL detector in the angular range 5–80° (2θ) with a measurement step of 0.039° (2θ) and a reading step time of 115.26 s. The resulting data were evaluated by the HighScore Plus 4.0. 2.2.5 Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out using the TA Instruments TGA Discovery series (TA Instruments, Lukens Drive, NW, USA). The apparatus operates in a temperature range from 40 to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in the flow of nitrogen (20 mL/min, Linde 5.0). Approximately 15 mg of sample was put inside an open alumina crucible and heated. The Quadrupole mass detector OmniStar GSD320 (Pfeiffer Vacuum Austria GmbH, Vienna, Austria) was used to detect the fragments. The measurement was carried out using SCAN mode with voltage 1450 V of electron multiplier. 2.2.6 Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) JSM-IT500HR from the Jeol group (Tokyo, Japan) was used for determination of the prepared catalysts’ surface structure. The distribution of metals on the surface of the prepared catalysts was determined from elemental maps of the samples obtained using energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). Representative secondary electron (SED) images of microstructures were taken in high vacuum mode using an accelerating voltage of 15 kV. The working distance was 10 mm and magnification range was from 10000x to 30000x. 2.3 Catalytic experiments The reactions were conducted in 25 mL round-bottom flasks with a sampling side-neck, equipped with a reflux condenser. The flasks were immersed in an oil bath placed on a magnetic stirrer and maintained at a temperature of 80 °C with constant stirring. In a typical experiment, 3 g of acetonitrile as a solvent, 0.5 g of the starting material and 0.1 g of the catalyst were introduced into the flask. After allowing the resulting suspension to reach the desired temperature, a 50 % hydrogen peroxide solution was added as the oxidizing agent. Hydrogen peroxide was gradually dosed in 10-minute intervals, with each dose being 0.05 mL. The total volume of the oxidizing agent added was 0.6 mL, corresponding to a 3.2-fold molar excess over the starting substance. The reaction was initiated with the addition of the first dose of the oxidizing agent, and samples were taken in regular intervals. The given reaction conditions were chosen based on our previous studies [33,35]. The collected samples were subsequently centrifuged to remove the catalyst and analysed using a Varian CP 3800 gas chromatograph equipped with a nonpolar CP-SIL 8 column (30 m long, diameter: 0.25 mm, stationary phase film thickness: 0.25 μm), along with an autosampler and FID detector. Nitrogen was used as the carrier gas. Identification of the reaction products was performed on a Shimadzu GC 2010 gas chromatograph coupled with a Shimadzu GC-MS QP 2010 Ultra mass detector (non-polar column DB-5-ms, 35 m long, 0.20 nm diameter, stationary phase film thickness: 0.33 μm), using helium as the carrier gas. 2.4 Evaluation of results The conversion X (A) (%) of the starting material was calculated using Eq. (1): (1) X A % = ( c A , 0 − c A , t ) c A , 0 ∙ 100 where cA,0 (%) is the analytical concentration of starting material at the beginning of the reaction, cA,t (%) is the analytical concentration of starting material in the sample taken at time t. The selectivity to the desired products was calculated using Eq. (2): (2) S x = ∑ c desired products ∑ c all products where cdesired products signifies the analytical concentration of the desired reaction products (formate and product of hydrolysis) and call products signifies the analytical concentration of all reaction products. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization For all prepared catalysts, X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis was conducted to determine the chemical composition, specific surface area was measured using the BET method, and acid-base properties were analysed via temperature-programmed desorption (TPD). The results of these characterizations of the mixed oxides are presented in Table 1 (for catalysts prepared by co-precipitation method) and Table 2 (for catalysts modified by impregnation method). The XRF analysis confirmed that the prepared mixed oxides contained molar ratios of the respective metal ions very close to the desired values. The specific surface area of all prepared catalysts was determined through nitrogen physisorption. As shown in Table 1, mixed oxides based on MgAl and ZnAl hydrotalcites exhibited significant differences in specific surface area. The unmodified Mg2Al mixed oxide demonstrated a specific surface area 2.6 times larger than that of Zn2Al, which is consistent with the results described in the literature [38]. This phenomenon can be explained by the different chemical nature of ZnO and MgO. The literature [39] describes higher crystallinity of ZnAl mixed oxides compared to MgAl mixed oxides, which reflects differences in energy and overall behavior at the solid–vapor interface. The intraparticle space in ZnAl mixed oxides is smaller than in MgAl mixed oxides, leading to a lower final specific surface area. In ZnMgAl mixed oxides, it is generally observed that the ionic radius of Zn2+ is larger than that of Mg2+, and Mg2+ is isomorphically substituted by Zn2+ in the Zn1Mg1Al-HT layer. As shown in Table 1, Mg2Al mixed oxides exhibited a higher specific surface area than Zn2Al mixed oxides, while the specific surface area of Zn1Mg1Al mixed oxides was approximately intermediate [38]. The obtained SBET values are consistent with those reported by the authors of references [40,41]. Additionally, the Mg2Al mixed oxide containing tin exhibited a specific surface area 5–6 times larger than that of similar modified mixed oxides based on Zn2Al hydrotalcite. Overall, the presence of Fe and Sn oxides in the structure of the Mg2Al mixed oxide contributes to an increase in its specific surface area, irrespective of the quantity of these metals and their molar ratio. It is known from the literature [21] that the size of the Sn4+ cation is relatively large (ionic radius of Sn4+ = 69 pm), therefore in the case of Sn0.5Mg2Al, where the tin content is relatively high, it likely partial obstructs the pores, resulting in a reduced specific surface area. In contrast, since iron atoms are smaller than tin atoms, a similar obstruction does not occur in the mixed oxide modified with iron at the same molar ratio (Fe0.5Mg2Al). Conversely, the incorporation of tin into the Zn2Al mixed oxide slightly decreased the specific surface area, which remained relatively low. For the mixed oxide containing both Mg and Zn oxides, the results obtained were consistent with a rough average between those of Mg2Al and Zn2Al, as expected. Mixed oxides based on MgAl, ZnAl and MgZnAl hydrotalcites, into which tin was introduced via the impregnation method, were also analysed using various analytical techniques (Table 2). The authors would like to emphasize that the study deals primarily with co-precipitated hydrotalcites. Impregnated ones are mentioned only for the purpose of comparing the influence of the method of tin incorporation into the hydrotalcite structure. A deeper and more detailed investigation of the synthesis and use of impregnated hydrotalcites has already been described in our previous studies [33–35]. For all three types of mixed oxides, the introduction of tin resulted in an increase in the specific surface area; however, the amount of impregnated tin did not significantly influence this property. As anticipated, MgAl mixed oxides exhibited the highest specific surface, while ZnAl mixed oxides showed the lowest one. Notably, the specific surface areas of tin-impregnated ZnAl and MgZnAl mixed oxides were higher than those of SnZnAl and SnMgZnAl, which were prepared by the co-precipitation method. Table 1 clearly shows that we successfully achieved our goal of preparing materials with significantly different acid-base properties. The basicity of mixed oxides based on MgAl hydrotalcites is approximately ten times greater than that of mixed oxides based on ZnAl hydrotalcites. In terms of acidity, the difference is less pronounced; MgAl mixed oxides are only about two times more acidic than their ZnAl counterparts. Furthermore, as indicated in Table 1, the basicity of the catalyst decreases slightly with an increasing amount of Fe, while an increase in the tin content corresponds to an increase in basicity. This trend is observed in both MgAl and ZnAl mixed oxides, as well as in the mixed MgZnAl catalysts. Additionally, the increasing tin content in the catalyst also results in a rise in acidity. However, the presence of iron does not exhibit such a clear impact on the acidity of the catalyst. Notably, the incorporation of tin in the MgZnAl mixed oxide surprisingly leads to a reduction in acidity by approximately one third. The presence of impregnated tin (Table 2) substantially reduced the basicity of all three types of hydrotalcites, with basicity decreasing as the amounts of tin increased. Conversely, a different trend was observed for acidity: the incorporation of tin in the mixed oxides led to an increase in acidity, which also rose with the increasing tin content. When comparing the acid-base properties of mixed oxides modified with tin by co-precipitation and impregnation methods, a consistent pattern emerged: the basicity of the impregnated mixed oxides was significantly lower than that of the co-precipitated counterparts, while their acidity was higher. The TPD-CO2 profiles ( Fig. 2 a) and Fig. 2 S a), SI) of the prepared mixed oxides exhibit a distinct sharp peak at around 120 °C, which, in the case of the MgAl-based mixed oxides, transitions into a broader second peak within the temperature range of 200–400 °C. The first visible peak is associated with the interaction of CO2 with weak basic sites related to surface hydroxyl groups. The second peak, appearing around 220 °C, corresponds to medium-strength basic sites associated with oxygen atoms in Mg2+–O2- and Al3+–O2- pairs. For the ZnAl-based mixed oxides, this second peak is not clearly distinguishable. However, as shown in Table 1 S (see SI), this does not imply that these catalysts possess only weak basic sites, although the ratio of weak to medium-strength basic sites is notably higher compared to the MgAl-based counterparts. Among the CO2 desorption profiles of the prepared catalysts, the most distinct behavior was observed for 5Sn-Mg2Al. As shown in Fig. 2 S a) (see SI), in contrast to the other samples, the second peak for this catalyst is much more intense than the first and is also shifted to 290 °C. Nevertheless, neither Table 2 nor Table 1 S (see SI) indicate any significant differences in the overall basic properties of this catalyst compared to the others. Strong basic sites associated with isolated O2- anions were not observed. After deconvolution of the TPD profiles, it was found that the ratio of medium-strength to weak basic sites varied depending on the catalyst composition. The highest amount of medium-strength basic sites was observed for the MgAl-based mixed oxides, both unmodified (Mg2Al) and modified with tin or a small amount of iron (Fe0.1Mg2Al). A higher Fe content led to a slight increase in the amount of weak basic sites. For ZnAl-based mixed oxides, the amount of medium-strength basic sites was nearly twice as low as that in the MgAl-based counterparts. Tin impregnation of Mg2Al resulted in a significant decrease in both the amount of medium-strength basic sites and the total basicity, as mentioned earlier, likely due to the occupation of potential basic sites on the catalyst surface by tin species. Fig. 2 b) and 2S b) (see SI) show the TPD profiles of pyridine desorption obtained for the prepared mixed oxides. For MgAl-based oxides, pyridine desorption starts at approximately 200 °C and reaches a maximum between 260 °C (for MgAl and co-precipitated SnMgAl) and 300 °C (for MgZnAl and impregnated SnMgAl). In ZnAl-based samples, the desorption peak is shifted by approximately 20–30 °C to higher temperatures. This pyridine desorption peak can be attributed to the presence of mainly medium-strength (200–300 °C) and strong (> 300 °C) acid sites on the catalyst surface. Weak acid sites associated with OH⁻ groups, typically observed below 200 °C, were not detected. [42] To confirm the formation of the crystalline structure corresponding to hydrotalcite-based mixed oxides, XRD analysis was performed for both the synthesized hydrotalcites and the mixed oxides derived from them. As shown in Fig. 3 a), c), and 3S a) (see SI), the highest crystallinity was observed for hydrotalcites containing Zn in their structure, reaching approximately 90 % (Table 2 S, SI). In contrast, the lowest crystallinity was found for Sn0.5Mg2Al and 5Sn-Mg2Al hydrotalcites, around 50 %. In this study, crystallinity is defined as the proportion of the crystalline phase in the sample and was calculated using the Rietveld refinement method. The XRD patterns of the corresponding mixed oxides (Fig. 3 b), d), and 3S b), SI) show significantly lower crystallinity compared to their hydrotalcite precursors, which is in line with expectations. Furthermore, ZnAl hydrotalcites exhibited a much smaller loss of crystallinity upon calcination compared to MgAl-based materials (Table 2 S, SI). Among the mixed oxides, an increasing tin content was found to slightly reduce the overall crystallinity of the materials. XRD analysis of the non-calcined hydrotalcites (Fig. 3 a), c), and Fig. 3 S a), SI) confirmed the formation of a typical hydrotalcite structure, corresponding to MgAl(OH)(CO3)(H2O) and ZnAl(OH)(CO3)(H2O) phases. The characteristic diffraction bands were observed at 2θ = 12°, 23°, 35°, 40°, 47°, 61°, and 62°. The only differences observed among the various hydrotalcite samples were in the intensity of the diffraction peaks. The mixed oxides (Fig. 3 b), d) and 3S b), SI) derived from MgAl hydrotalcite exhibit characteristic MgO periclase diffraction lines at 2θ = 35°, 43° and 63°. Notably, the diffraction bands associated with iron are not visible, regardless of its concentration. Conversely, the diffraction bands corresponding to romarchite (SnO), 2θ = 27° and 52°, are observed only in the mixed oxide with the highest tin amount (Sn:Mg:Al = 0.5:2:1) among all prepared catalysts. For mixed oxides based on ZnAl hydrotalcite, characteristic diffraction bands corresponding to ZnO are evident at 2θ = 33°, 36°, 48°, 57°, 69°. Due to the low concentration of tin incorporated into the Sn0.07Zn2Al hydrotalcite structure, the diffraction bands associated with tin are not detectable. In the case of the MgZnAl mixed oxide, the XRD pattern is dominated by characteristic diffraction bands corresponding to ZnO at 2θ = 33°, 36°, and 57°. Since the first two reflections form a broad peak with two maxima, they likely overlap with the band characteristic of MgO at 2θ = 35°. For the 5Sn-MgZnAl sample, an additional reflection is observed at 2θ = 63°, which is nearly as intense as the one at 2θ = 57°, and can be attributed to MgO. However, no distinct reflections for MgO are observed elsewhere in the diffractograms. This can be attributed to two key factors. First, the intensity of MgO reflections in mixed oxides is significantly reduced due to the homogeneous dispersion of Al₂O₃ within the MgO matrix. Second, the presence of impregnated SnO₂ further decreases the overall crystallinity and diffraction signal intensity. The combination of these two effects suppresses the visibility of MgO reflections, even though MgO is present in the sample. For certain characterization techniques just a representative catalyst from different groups was selected. The selection was made so that the chosen catalyst could serve as a representative of a specific subgroup of structurally and compositionally similar materials, while its properties remained comparable with those of catalysts from other subgroups in the context of the given analytical method. The TGA-MS method was employed to investigate the thermal decomposition of the prepared hydrotalcites during calcination. Fig. 4 a) illustrates the relationship between sample weight loss and increasing temperature, which is characteristic of the thermal decomposition of hydrotalcites. Fig. 4 b) presents the derivative curves of the obtained results. The thermal decomposition of hydrotalcites can be categorized into three distinct steps. The most significant mass loss occurs in the 1st step, within the temperature range of 50–200 °C. During this phase, physically absorbed water is released from the surface of the samples between 50 and 100 °C, followed by the release of interlayer water from the hydrotalcite structure between 100 and 200 °C [21,43]. In the 2nd step, occurring between 200 and 400 °C, hydroxyl groups decompose and CO3 2- carbonate groups are released from the brucite layers of the hydrotalcites [44]. The subsequent temperature increase leads to the decarbonization of the hydrotalcite layers and the complete decomposition of the hydrotalcite structure into mixed oxides [45]. The most substantial weight loss (over 45 %) was observed for Mg2Al hydrotalcite (Fig. 4 a) and Table 3 S, SI). In contrast, Zn2Al hydrotalcite exhibited the least weight loss (approximately 30 %). Notably, the second inflection point visible in the curves for ZnAl-based hydrotalcites in the range from 300 °C to 400 °C (Fig. 4 b)) suggests that ZnAl-based catalysts contain fewer hydroxyl and carbonate groups bound to the brucite layers. This observation aligns with their significantly lower basicity and acidity. The release of water, monitored via mass spectrometry (Fig. 4 c)) confirmed the hypothesis that water removal predominantly occurs within the temperature range of 50–500 °C. The release of CO₂ (Fig. 4 d)) was observed for all catalysts across various temperature intervals. Specifically, for all catalysts containing Zn, the first peak appeared around 120 °C, likely corresponding to the release of CO₂ adsorbed from the atmosphere. Additionally, for all hydrotalcites containing Mg, a peak was detected in the temperature range of 300–500 °C, correlating with the release of carbonates from the catalyst layers. Lastly, all prepared hydrotalcites exhibited peaks in the temperature range of approximately 600–800 °C (with ZnAl hydrotalcites displaying two peaks, the second around 810 °C), likely associated with the release of carbonates from the structure of mixed oxides. To investigate morphological differences arising during the calcination of hydrotalcites and to compare the morphology of mixed oxides derived from MgAl, ZnAl, and MgZnAl hydrotalcites, SEM images of the prepared catalysts were obtained ( Fig. 5 a) and b)). Both the uncalcined MgAl hydrotalcite and its corresponding mixed oxide exhibited the characteristic lamellar particle structure typical of MgAl-hydrotalcite materials. In the case of uncalcined FeMgAl and SnMgAl hydrotalcites (Fig. 5 a)), larger aggregates of smaller, smoothly surfaced particles were observed, indicating a high degree of crystallinity (Table 2 S, SI). Upon calcination (Fig. 5 b)), these crystalline structures decomposed to form mixed oxides, accompanied by a morphological transformation into a lamellar structure. Catalysts based on ZnAl hydrotalcites displayed a pronounced flaky and plate-like morphology, which became even more distinct after calcination but otherwise remained unchanged. This observation is consistent with the TGA results (Table 2 S, SI), which showed that the ZnAl mixed oxides exhibited only slightly lower crystallinity compared to the uncalcined hydrotalcites. The incorporation of tin into these materials had no observable effect on their morphology. The MgZnAl hydrotalcite exhibited a morphology similar to that of FeMgAl and SnMgAl, consisting of larger aggregates of smaller, smooth-surfaced particles. However, after calcination, both lamellar structures characteristic of MgAl and flake-like structures typical of ZnAl became apparent, in agreement with expectations. When comparing the SEM images acquired at higher range (Fig. 4 S a) and b), SI), it is evident that the size and shape of the flakes vary significantly between different types of catalysts. However, within each individual catalyst, the morphology of the lamellae or flakes is relatively uniform. The distribution of active sites across the surface of such similar particles is particularly important in this context. To assess the uniformity of metal distribution on the surface of the mixed oxide particles, EDX images were obtained. Fig. 6 demonstrates that all metals, including tin and iron, are uniformly distributed across the surface of the particles. 3.2 Catalytic testing The catalytic activity of all prepared catalysts was evaluated using the Baeyer-Villiger (BV) oxidation of myrtenal and β-cyclocitral, with reactions conducted as outlined in Section 2.3. The results of these experiments are presented in Table 3. In the BV oxidation of myrtenal, the second reaction step – hydrolysis - occurred immediately following the formation of formate, so only nopinone was detected in the reaction mixture, as the intermediate formate was fully converted. For the BV oxidation of β-cyclocitral, however, hydrolysis of the resulting formate was slower, allowing for the detection of both target products in the reaction mixture. One of the aims of this study was to investigate the influence of the acid-base properties of the prepared hydrotalcite-derived mixed oxides on the course of the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of myrtenal and β-cyclocitral. To facilitate this analysis, the catalytic results presented in Table 3, together with the TPD data shown in Tables 1 and 2, were combined and summarized in four tables ( Table 4 S a) – d), SI). For clarity, the catalysts are grouped and visually separated according to their structural types. Within each group, the mixed oxides are arranged in order of increasing conversion of the respective substrates. This format enables a more comprehensive and transparent comparison across all catalyst groups and better highlights the impact of acid–base properties on conversion for both substrates. Arrows indicate increasing trends in basicity or acidity. Catalysts that do not follow the observed trend are marked in italics. In most cases, these outliers are represented by the unmodified Mg2Al mixed oxide, which was included in each group of MgAl-hydrotalcite based catalysts for comparison purposes. First, we tested the catalytic activity of mixed oxides based on MgAl hydrotalcite. The catalyst Mg2Al (Table 3 , exp. 1) demonstrated comparable activity with both substrates, achieving a conversion rate of 40 % after 5 h. However, the selectivity towards the desired products varied significantly between reactions. For nopinone, selectivity was high at 85 %, with myrtenic acid being the only observed by-product. In contrast, the selectivity for Baeyer-Villiger (BV) oxidation products of β-cyclocitral was lower, around 35 %, with a 1:1 ratio of the two products. The primary by-products included 1,1,3-trimethylcyclohexane, (2,2,6-trimethylcyclohexyl)methanol, and a carboxylic acid. Adding iron into the MgAl hydrotalcite structure (Table 3 , exp. 2–4) did not notably affect myrtenal conversion compared to Mg2Al itself but led to over a two-fold decrease in selectivity to nopinone, with selectivity decreasing further as iron content increased. For β-cyclocitral, however, iron showed a beneficial effect on conversion, where higher iron content correlated with increased conversion rates. Despite this fact, selectivity to the desired products decreased even further, and hydrolysis rates slowed. The primary by-products here were 1,1,3-trimethylcyclohexane and (2,2,6-trimethylcyclohexyl)methanol, indicating reduction process. From Table 4 S a) – d) (see SI), it is evident that the conversion of the starting materials is, for almost all groups of mixed oxides, closely related to their acid–base properties. In the case of FeMgAl-based mixed oxides, the conversion of both substrates increases with decreasing acidity and basicity (including a decreasing ratio of weak to medium-strength basic sites, see Table 1 S) (see SI), which in turn correlates with an increasing iron content. Incorporation of tin into the FeMgAl mixed oxide structure in selected ratios reversed these trends—conversions of both substrates increased with increasing acidity and basicity. However, since both Sn/Fe ratios exhibited very similar acidities and comparable ratios of weak to medium-strength basic sites, it is not surprising that similar substrate conversions were achieved for both catalyst compositions. Therefore, no clear or consistent correlation between catalytic activity and the acid–base properties of the catalysts can be established in this particular case. Regarding selectivity to the desired products, an opposite trend was observed for both reactions with FeMgAl/SnFeMgAl mixed oxides: catalyst with higher basicity achieved higher selectivity for the target products. Increased acidity also positively influenced selectivity for nopinone. However, the selectivity for the products of BV oxidation of β-cyclocitral was largely unaffected by the acidity of the catalysts. If only tin was incorporated into the structure of MgAl hydrotalcite (Table 3 , exp. 7–9), higher conversion values of myrtenal were achieved compared to those obtained using FeMgAl (Table 3 , exp. 2–4) or SnFeMgAl (Table 3 , exp. 5–6) mixed oxides. The conversion of myrtenal and selectivity to nopinone increased with the amount of tin present. In this case, the increases in basicity and acidity (Table 4 S a) and b), SI) associated with higher tin content positively impacted not only the selectivity to nopinone but also the overall conversion of myrtenal. It should be noted that all SnMgAl mixed oxides exhibited the same, consistently high ratio of medium-strength to weak basic sites: 1:2.9 in favor of the medium-strength ones. This feature also had a beneficial effect on the reaction performance. The excellent catalytic properties of tin itself in the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of myrtenal 33 probably play a significant role here. When comparing the catalytic activity of Fe0.5Mg2Al and Sn0.5Mg2Al (Table 3 , exp. 4 and 9), the use of Sn0.5Mg2Al resulted in nearly total conversion of myrtenal with three times higher selectivity to nopinone after 5 h of reaction. For β-cyclocitral, the trend observed with SnMgAl mixed oxides mirrored that of FeMgAl mixed oxides: lower β-cyclocitral conversion values were obtained when catalysts with higher basicity and acidity were employed (Table 4 S c) and d), SI). Specifically, when comparing the iron-based mixed oxide Fe0.5Mg2Al (Table 3 , exp. 4 and 9) with Sn0.5Mg2Al, the latter achieved nearly 2 times lower conversion of β-cyclocitral. However, the selectivity to the desired products was 2.5 times higher with Sn0.5Mg2Al. This result was anticipated, considering that Sn0.5Mg2Al exhibited significantly higher basicity and acidity compared to Fe0.5Mg2Al. The highest values of the conversion of both starting substances and selectivity for the desired products were achieved using ZnAl mixed oxides (Table 3 , exp. 10–12). Interestingly, the presence of tin in the structure of this type of catalyst had a slight negative effect on the reaction results. These catalysts exhibited the lowest values of basicity and acidity (Table 1), as well as the lowest specific surface area among all prepared catalysts. This observation reinforces the trend where lower values of acidity and basicity correlate with higher conversion rates of the starting materials (Table 4 S a) - d), SI). However, contrary to expectations based on this trend, the selectivity for the desired products was not low, suggesting that ZnAl mixed oxides are more selective for the formation of Baeyer-Villiger (BV) oxidation products than MgAl mixed oxides. As shown in Table 3 (exp. 10–12), the main product of the BV oxidation of β-cyclocitral using ZnAl mixed oxides is formate, and the selectivity for the product of its subsequent hydrolysis is comparable to that obtained with SnMgAl mixed oxides. When comparing the catalytic activity of SnMgAl (Table 3 , exp. 7–8) and SnZnAl (Table 3 , exp. 11–12) mixed oxides, it is evident that myrtenal and β-cyclocitral underwent almost 2 times higher conversion when using SnZnAl, along with higher selectivity values. When using MgZnAl mixed oxide (Table 3 , exp. 13), lower conversion values of the starting substances were observed compared to the ZnAl mixed oxide (Table 3 , exp. 10), as expected, but higher than those achieved with the MgAl mixed oxide (Table 3 , exp. 1). The presence of Mg in the structure of the ZnAl catalyst had no significant effect on the selectivity to the desired products. Similar to the results obtained with SnMgAl mixed oxides (Table 3 , exp. 7–9), a higher tin content led to increased conversion values for myrtenal, while β-cyclocitral conversion values decreased (Table 3 , exp. 14). A portion of the prepared MgAl, ZnAl and MgZnAl catalysts was subsequently impregnated with 3 and 5 wt% of tin to evaluate the influence of the tin incorporation method on catalytic activity for the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of myrtenal and β-cyclocitral. As shown in Table 4 S a) – d) (see SI), all impregnated catalysts exhibit increasing conversion of both substrates with decreasing basicity and increasing acidity. The impregnation of tin onto the MgAl mixed oxide (Table 3 , exp. 15–16) had only a minor effect on its catalytic performance. As a result, very similar BV oxidation results were obtained for both myrtenal and β-cyclocitral compared to the unmodified Mg2Al catalyst (Table 3 , exp. 1), both in terms of conversion and selectivity. A higher tin loading led to a slightly positive effect on the conversion and selectivity of myrtenal, although the impact remained minimal. In contrast, the BV oxidation of β-cyclocitral was unaffected by the amount of impregnated tin. When comparing the results of BV oxidation catalyzed by the impregnated 5Sn-Mg2Al (Table 3 , exp. 16) and the co-precipitated Sn0.05Mg2Al (Table 3 , exp. 7), identical conversion and selectivity to nopinone were observed for myrtenal. However, the use of 5Sn-Mg2Al in the oxidation of β-cyclocitral resulted in a 1.5-fold lower conversion and selectivity compared to the Sn0.05Mg2Al catalyst. Conversely, for the other two types of mixed oxides (Table 3 , exp. 17–20), the incorporation of tin via impregnation adversely impacted both the conversion of the substrates and the selectivity toward the desired products. Notably, for all 3 of mixed oxides categories, a higher concentration of impregnated tin resulted in enhanced conversion of myrtenal, mirroring the trends observed in reactions catalysed by SnMgAl mixed oxides (Table 3 , exp. 7–9). However, the conversion of β-cyclocitral and the selectivity for both reactions remained unaffected by the level of tin incorporation. It is worth noting that the impregnated mixed oxides exhibited significantly lower basicity compared to those synthesized through coprecipitation, yet demonstrated markedly higher acidity (Table 2). This divergence in acid-base properties underscores the complexity of catalytic behaviour, where the interplay between basicity and acidity can distinctly influence reaction pathways and product distributions. An attempt was made to correlate the strength of basic sites with catalytic performance in Baeyer–Villiger oxidation reactions (Tables 3 and 1 S); however, no clear trend was observed. This confirms that the effect of acid–base characteristics on the catalytic outcome is multifactorial. Nevertheless, a general tendency was noted: when the ratio of weak to medium-strength basic sites exceeds 1:2.5, lower conversion and selectivity are typically observed. 3.3 Recycling of catalysts One of the most important parameters of heterogeneous catalysts for long-term use is their stability. In this study, the stability of the prepared catalysts was evaluated by testing their reusability in BV oxidation of myrtenal. For comparison, four mixed oxides based on MgAl and ZnAl hydrotalcites were selected, into whose structure tin was introduced either by the co-precipitation (Sn0.05Mg2Al and Sn0.05Zn2Al) or impregnation (5Sn-Mg2Al and 5Sn-Zn2Al) method. The reusability of these catalysts was tested over three reaction cycles. After each cycle, a portion of the catalyst was taken for analysis to determine any changes in composition or structure compared to the fresh mixed oxide reference. Due to potential catalyst mass losses during post-reaction processing and sample collection for characterization at each intermediate step, the first BV oxidation cycle was conducted on a 10-fold larger scale (Table 4) than described in Section 2.3. The second reaction cycle was performed on a 4-fold larger scale, and the third cycle was conducted at the same scale as described in the aforementioned section. To determine whether any structural or compositional changes occurred during recycling, the four tested catalysts were subjected to XRF and XRD analyses before and after at least two reaction cycles. The XRD analysis of Mg2Al and Zn2Al catalysts was conducted at the following stages: a) HT before calcination, b) MO after calcination (i.e., before the impregnation of 5 wt% tin), c) Sn-HT after tin impregnation and before calcination, d) Sn-MO after calcination (i.e., prior to the first reaction cycle), e) Sn-HT after the first reaction cycle, where the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture, washed with acetonitrile, and dried overnight at 110 °C, but not yet calcined, f) Sn-MO after the first reaction cycle and subsequent calcination (i.e., prior to the second reaction cycle). In the case of Sn0.05Mg2Al and Sn0.05Zn2Al catalysts, steps b) and c) were omitted as no tin impregnation was performed for these materials. The results of the BV oxidation obtained after each of the three reaction cycles (Table 4) were compared with those obtained using the fresh reference catalyst under standard reaction conditions (see Section 2.3). As shown in Table 4, all four catalysts exhibited a decrease in conversion by approximately one third when the reaction was carried out on a 10-fold larger scale, compared to the results obtained under standard conditions. This decrease is most likely related to the method of hydrogen peroxide addition. In our previous studies [33,35], we investigated the influence of different dosing methods and found that gradual addition in smaller portions at more frequent intervals leads to better performance. This is due to the rapid decomposition of hydrogen peroxide in the reaction mixture. In the present study, to allow for proper comparison, the same dosing procedure was maintained during the recyclability tests, even at the increased reaction scale, as described under standard conditions in Section 2.3. In terms of stability, the mixed oxides derived from MgAl and ZnAl hydrotalcites exhibit markedly different behaviour. For both MgAl-based mixed oxides, a slight increase in conversion was observed with each subsequent reaction cycle. While this could suggest enhanced catalytic activity over time, the more probable explanation is the gradual downscaling of the reaction volume. In the third cycle, conducted under standard reaction conditions, the results matched those obtained with the fresh reference catalyst under identical conditions. This indicates that MgAl-based mixed oxides are highly stable and retain their activity over at least three consecutive reaction cycles. This assumption is further supported by XRF analysis ( Table 5), which showed only a slight decrease in the concentrations of tin and magnesium. However, this may be attributed to the accumulation of organic residues from the reaction mixture on the catalyst surface, which could compromise the accuracy of the analysis. This surface contamination might also account for the notably low crystallinity observed in the uncalcined SnMgAl catalysts after the first reaction cycle (Table 5 S, SI). Nevertheless, their subsequent recalcination restored the crystallinity values to those of the fresh mixed oxide (approximately 30 %). In contrast, when ZnAl-based mixed oxides were used in BV oxidation, a gradual decrease in conversion was observed with each successive reaction cycle. This decline was more pronounced in the case of Sn0.05Zn2Al. XRF analysis (Table 5) revealed that in the case of 5Sn-Zn2Al, there was a more significant loss of tin with each reaction cycle compared to 5Sn-Mg2Al. A slight decrease in Zn content was also observed. On the other hand, for Sn0.05Zn2Al, the tin content remained nearly unchanged, while the Zn loss was more substantial. This behavior is attributed to the method of tin incorporation—whereas in coprecipitated hydrotalcites tin is integrated directly into the structure and thus more strongly bound, in impregnated materials it is mainly deposited on the surface and more prone to leaching. Based on the obtained results, it can be concluded that ZnAl-based mixed oxides are less stable than their MgAl counterparts and exhibit limited reusability. According to Table 5 S (see SI), BV oxidation again led to a decrease in the crystallinity of the SnZnAl mixed oxides; however, this decrease was far less pronounced than that observed for the SnMgAl hydrotalcites. Nevertheless, in the case of 5Sn-Zn2Al, unlike the SnMgAl-based mixed oxides, recalcination did not restore the crystallinity to the level of the fresh MO. From the XRD analysis ( Fig. 7 a) – d)), similar trends were observed for all four selected catalysts. Both the impregnation process and use in the reaction resulted in a significant decrease in the intensity of diffraction peaks. As shown in Fig. 7 a) – d), the diffractograms of the uncalcined hydrotalcites after the first reaction cycle display diffraction peaks corresponding to mixed oxides. Peaks characteristic of the hydrotalcite structure were not detected in the catalysts recovered from the reaction mixture, indicating that—despite the presence of water in the reaction medium—no partial rehydration or reconstruction of the crystalline hydrotalcite structure occurred during the reaction. When comparing the influence of substrate structure - specifically, myrtenal and β-cyclocitral - on the course of the Baeyer-Villiger (BV) oxidation catalyzed by mixed oxides derived from MgAl, ZnAl, and MgZnAl hydrotalcites, several trends can be observed. With the exception of reactions catalyzed by iron-modified mixed oxides, both substrates reached very similar conversion levels after 5 h of reaction. However, the selectivity towards the desired products differed significantly between the two compounds. Myrtenal, a bicyclic molecule with pronounced steric hindrance, was considerably more prone to undergo BV oxidation followed by hydrolysis than the monocyclic β-cyclocitral. In the case of myrtenal, the intermediate formate was rapidly hydrolyzed to nopinone, to such an extent that it was not detected in the reaction mixture during analysis. The only notable by-product was myrtenic acid, whose concentration generally did not exceed 10 %. In contrast, the formate derived from β-cyclocitral - which, as a monocyclic molecule with lower steric hindrance, is less susceptible to hydrolysis - remained the predominant product in most reactions. Furthermore, in addition to the expected carboxylic acid, other compounds such as 1,1,3-trimethylcyclohexane and (2,2,6-trimethylcyclohexyl)methanol were detected in the reaction mixture, indicating concurrent reduction processes. These observations suggest that while the substrate structure does not significantly affect the activity of MgAl-, ZnAl-, or MgZnAl-based mixed oxide catalysts, it plays a crucial role in determining the selectivity towards the desired products. Larger, more sterically hindered molecules tend to undergo BV oxidation and subsequent hydrolysis more readily. 4 Conclusions In this study, a series of mixed oxides derived from MgAl, ZnAl, and MgZnAl hydrotalcites was successfully synthesized and modified with tin and iron via co-precipitation and impregnation techniques. The materials were thoroughly characterized to clarify the relationships between their structure, composition, and catalytic behavior in Baeyer–Villiger (BV) oxidations. The key scientific advancement lies in establishing clear correlations between acid-base properties, metal composition, and catalytic performance. ZnAl-based oxides, characterized by low acidity and basicity, exhibited the highest conversions and selectivities for both myrtenal and β-cyclocitral. In contrast, MgAl-based oxides showed improved selectivity after tin modification, which increased both acidity and basicity. TPD and pyridine-adsorption studies confirmed that the balance and strength of acid-base sites directly influenced the product distribution. Iron-containing catalysts, despite exhibiting lower acid-base site densities, achieved high conversion in β-cyclocitral oxidation but showed poor selectivity, highlighting the importance of site nature over mere concentration. The method of catalyst preparation also played an important role. Catalysts with tin added by co-precipitation based on MgAl hydrotalcites kept their structure and activity during repeated use. In contrast, ZnAl-catalysts with tin added by impregnation gradually lost activity, likely due to tin leaching and a drop in crystallinity. The structure of the substrate also influenced the course of the reaction. Myrtenal, which is more sterically hindered, mainly underwent BV oxidation and hydrolysis, while β-cyclocitral reacted through multiple pathways, including reduction. Overall, this study demonstrates that the controlled incorporation of tin and iron into mixed oxides is an effective strategy for tuning their physicochemical and catalytic properties. The findings confirm that adjusting the acidity and basicity of the catalysts can enhance their activity and selectivity in Baeyer–Villiger oxidations. However, the final catalytic performance also depends on the interaction between the catalyst and the substrate, as well as on the synthesis method used. coredata.dc:description: Mixed oxides derived from MgAl, ZnAl, and MgZnAl hydrotalcites were prepared and modified with tin and iron using co-precipitation and impregnation methods. Comprehensive characterization by XRD, XRF, BET, TPD, TGA, SEM, and EDX revealed that metal composition and method of modification strongly influenced crystallinity, surface area, and acid-base properties. Tin incorporation increased acidity and basicity, while iron reduced both, with structural impacts varying by matrix. The catalysts were tested in the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of myrtenal and β-cyclocitral. ZnAl-based oxides showed the highest conversion and selectivity (almost total conversion of both starting substances after 5 h of the reaction, with selectivity to nopinone reaching approximately 95 % and selectivity to the products of β-cyclocitral oxidation around 70 %, predominantly yielding formate), while tin-modified MgAl catalysts provided stable performance with enhanced selectivity. Substrate structure significantly influenced product distribution, with myrtenal favouring oxidation–hydrolysis pathways and β-cyclocitral undergoing additional reduction. Reusability studies demonstrated excellent stability of SnMgAl catalysts over three consecutive reaction cycles, with minimal leaching and full recovery of crystallinity after recalcination. In contrast, SnZnAl catalysts showed gradual deactivation, especially when tin was introduced via impregnation. The study highlights the importance of fine-tuning acid-base and structural properties of mixed oxides through metal incorporation and preparation method. The findings offer valuable insights into the rational design of robust and selective catalysts for Baeyer-Villiger oxidations.
